answers.answer: The more weight you have packed around your middle (abdomen), the more you are at risk - heart disease, high cholesterol, high blood pressure, diabetes, etc.  For females that's a waist size greater than 35" and for males greater than 40".  Your height/weight puts you at an unhealthy BMI.But boy do I sympathize.  We all know the stats but keeping weight under control is a lot of work.  Eating is so much fun.Running is excellent.  Maybe try adding some weight training and walking on your off-running days.  Do something most days of the week.  For me, running, regular workouts and eating mini-meals has helped immensely.  And that includes treats - I don't deny myself.  It really is about calories in and calories out.At 50 I weight 115 lbs (5'3").  My family history is atrocious with several close relatives having had gastric bypass for obesity.  The above regime has worked wonders for keeping my weight under control.Good luck to you.

Try to avoid restaurant food whenever you can. If you find you have to go to a restaurant try "generously" passing off portions of your food onto others or just leaving half on the plate. A little evil yes, but better your work colleagues overeat than you ;-)

My best advice is cook at home as much as possible and avoid fast foods, restaurants and takeout.  Those foods tend to be much higer in fat and calories than their home cooked counterparts.  There is also an excellent program called Spark People.  Google it.  It's awesome and has helped a lot of people get on track.  And it's free!I wish you the best with your efforts to stay healthy.

question: I 'm 39 and had angioplasty for a heart blockage last year. I take 40 MG Lipitor, 75 MG Plavix and 81 MG asprin daily. My BP and pulse have always been good -- 118/80 and 56 last check. I have bad family history -- early heart attacks and premature death in men on both sides. I am a 3 mile a day runner, 4-5 days a week. With Lipitor, my cholesterol is good -- 127 total and 32/76 hdl/ldl.Yet I am overweight and I am wondering how much I should worry about that. I weigh about 225 and I'm 5-foot-10. I have long struggled to bring it down and only had success when I followed the Atkins diet, but I am afraid to go that route now that I know I have heart disease.I really struggle to eat right. I do pretty well at avoiding the obvious bad foods, like beef and fried items, but I tend to over eat no matter what I have for a meal. I eat a lot of salad, hummos, granola, yogart and oatmeal in my daily routine, and I stick to water and sugar-free, non-carbonated drinks (and I have quit caffine). But I tend to binge on pizza, sandwiches, creamy soups, fruit, pudding, and the like at restaurants, meetings, etc. Any advice here? I keep praying for a safe, effective appetite drug to come along.
title: Heart disease and weight loss
